TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to changes in the structure of the Ministry and the system of government departments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the recent general election at which the Government was returned for a third term of office, I announced a range of significant changes to the structure of the Ministry and of government departments. The Parliament will shortly consider the legislation which gives effect to or flows from aspects of those changes. For the information of the House, I wish today to outline the overall intent of the changes and their impact, including ways they may be reflected in the operations of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Since our first election in 1983 this Government has consistently developed policies to reconstruct our economy so that it can meet the challenges of a rapidly changing world trading environment. It is not simply a task for our trade-exposed sectors like agriculture, mining or, increasingly, manufacturing and tourism. It is a task for the whole economy, because all sectors can suffer if one is inefficient. In applying measures to deal with the responsible reconstruction of the economy, we are determined to apply the same rigour to the Government's own household.

Honourable members will be aware that early in its life, this Government embarked upon a program of reform of public administration. In pursuing a sound administrative basis for the development of its policies, the Government has addressed fundamental issues and implemented far-reaching reform measures. The reforms were given a legislative basis in the 1984 Public Service reform package, and have been augmented progressively by Budget reforms, the 1986 streamlining measures and, perhaps most importantly, the arrangements I announced in July last.

The Government has been concerned with two basic objectives: to enhance ministerial control over the Public Service and to give to departmental managers more responsibility for day to day management. By establishing mechanisms for greater ministerial control, we have been intent upon increasing the responsiveness of the bureaucracy to the Government's wishes and upon increasing democratic accountability, through Ministers, to Parliament and the community. The second of the objectives, greater responsibility for departmental management, has entailed the devolution of management functions from central agencies to individual departments and a new emphasis on the development of management skills in senior public servants. With greater freedom to manage, departments are in a better position to demonstrate their success in achieving the dual aims of increased efficiency and financial savings.

The Government's previous reform measures have resulted in considerable progress towards the achievement of our objectives. The revamping of Budget processes has given Ministers more direct involvement in the way resources are used within their portfolios. The introduction of program and staff budgeting has allowed the Government to tighten up resource allocation, while giving to Secretaries and other departmental managers greater freedom and responsibility in applying resources to the implementation of Government policies. The major package of measures I announced last year resulted in an important streamlining of personnel management practices.

With this experience behind us, I decided after the Government's re-election to proceed further along the path of administrative reform. The administrative arrangements approved by the Governor-General in Council on 24 July represented perhaps the most far-reaching reshaping of the Federal machinery of government and of public administration in our history. The number of departments has been reduced from 28 to 18, providing scope for savings through economies of scale and the removal of overlap and duplication across many areas of hitherto separate bureaucratic units.

To provide for enhanced ministerial control over the new range of departments, many of which are significantly enlarged, I decided, following receipt of an opinion from the Solicitor-General, that it was time we adopted a two-level ministerial structure and increased the number of Ministers. Under the new arrangements, the burden of administering departments is shared, and portfolio Ministers are released from some detailed administrative work, enabling them to give greater attention to strategic directions of policy and priorities. All portfolios are represented in Cabinet without the need for Cabinet to be expanded to an unmanageable size.

I am pleased to report that these arrangements have been in place now for seven weeks and are working well. Portfolio Ministers are ultimately responsible for the administration of their entire portfolios and will be accountable to the Parliament for the overall operation of their portfolios. All Ministers, however, have a clear accountability within specific responsibilities allocated to them. This accountability includes responding to questions without notice in the Parliament. I announced the allocation of responsibilities on 11 August, but for the information of the House, and as a guide to honourable members in the direction of questions, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list showing the division of functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Within their areas of responsibility all Ministers will be available to answer questions in the Parliament, and will, of course, take an active role in the legislative process. Within the Parliament, the changes will bring a number of benefits. The combination of the additional Ministers, and of portfolio Ministers having a wider spectrum of responsibility across major sectors of government activity, means the Ministers will be placed in a better position in both chambers to be responsive to the Parliament and its members. This will apply particularly in the Senate where the number of Senate Ministers will have been increased from six to eight, after Parliament enacts the relevant legislation, thus augmenting the capacity of the Government to respond to the concerns before that chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I should add that, in the meantime, pending the amendment of the Ministers of State Act to permit the appointment of 30 Ministers, there are three Parliamentary Secretaries, two of whom are in the Senate. It is intended that the people holding these positions will be sworn as Ministers as soon as possible. Until that time, as they are not Ministers, they will not answer questions without notice, carry legislation or perform chamber duty.

In allocating functions among departments we have been able to provide for improved co-ordination and broader perspectives within portfolios. We have increased our capacity for imposing functional and strategic directions on government activity in the major areas of economic reform on which Australia's response to the challenges of a highly competitive international environment depends.

The new arrangements allow for greater speed and consistency in the delivery of services and advice to the public. The abolition of the Public Service Board takes its place in this package of reforms designed to eliminate duplication of functions and as a further step in the process of increasing departmental responsibilities. All operational aspects of personnel matters are now to be devolved to departments.

A new Office of Public Service Commissioner will have responsibility for the policy aspects of recruitment, promotion, mobility, discipline and retirement, and for monitoring continuing progress in relation to equal employment opportunity. A part time Public Service Management Advisory Board will advise the Government on significant issues relating to the management of the Public Service. Public Service pay and conditions matters are to be transferred from the Board to the Department of Industrial Relations; and some aspects of classification issues have been transferred to the Department of Finance.

The services of Mr David Block, of which the Government has been most appreciative, will continue to be available to me and the Government. His unit, now called the Administrative Reform Unit, is currently overseeing the preparation of reports on matters such as the possible integration of Social Security and Commonwealth Employment Service local offices, the use of the Department of Social Security as a payment agency, a single foreign service and the future of the National Capital Development Commission. The task the Government has set itself in this area is wide-ranging and ongoing. To ensure that it receives proper co-operation and sustained momentum I have set up a special committee of the Cabinet, under the chairmanship of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), specifically to address Public Service reform.

The revised ministerial and administrative arrangements which I have summarised today are an important part of the Government's strategy of concentrating on its policy priorities while working within a streamlined structure which reflects both the need for financial restraint and the importance of responsiveness and effectiveness. I believe that the arrangements will provide a sound basis from which to undertake the task of meeting the present and future policy needs of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes many aspects of the changed administrative arrangements which were announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) after the election and which have been explained in more detail by him today. The concept of having a number of Ministers sworn to administer a particular department is certainly a concept that the Opposition supports. I welcome the fact that apparently the legal advice flowing to government on this subject has become a little more adventurous and a little more positive than it apparently has been to successive administrations over the years. But the Opposition does, nonetheless, welcome that as a very sensible administrative change. I think there is merit in the concept of having a number of Ministers sworn to administer the same department. The old idea that one had to create a shell department in order to have another Minister performing in the same general area as an existing Minister was an anachronistic one. I am very pleased indeed that the Government has been able to put that behind it.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of the amalgamations and consolidations of departments that have been announced by the Government are also welcomed by the Opposition. They mirror, in a number of quite crucial areas, declared policy positions taken by the Opposition. I therefore welcome the opportunity of saying to the House that the Opposition will be able to support large elements of the reforms announced by the Prime Minister. We will have an opportunity when legislation dealing with this, and also with the increase in the size of the Ministry which falls into a slightly different category, comes before the Parliament. But I say to the Prime Minister that any bureaucratic reform, no matter how adventurous, how far reaching and how sweeping it is, will fall to the ground unless the whole cornerstone of our system of government-that is, the concept of ministerial responsibility-is rigorously observed.

The real test of the third Hawke Government in the area of administrative conduct and administrative behaviour will be whether the standards that were not imposed during the first and second Hawke Ministries on ministerial conduct are, in fact, imposed during the third Hawke Ministry. The first test will be whether the Prime Minister responds appropriately to the behaviour of a number of his Ministers regarding the coastal surveillance debacle. If ever we had an example of the Westminster principle of ministerial responsibility applying, it ought to apply to the former Minister for Transport. His conduct is not a failure by a Minister, it is not a dereliction of ministerial duty and it is not a failure of ministerial responsibility. According to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) all that happened was that there was a systems failure. That is the new euphemism for a Minister not doing his job. I wonder what the present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) would have thought of that back in April 1982 when he said:

Nothing is more important than the way in which these people who are called Ministers behave themselves and set an example to other people in Australia. Nothing is more important than the relationship between the Government and the people of Australia.

The reality is that on the Amann Aviation scandal the Government was warned four months ago that it was not doing its job. The Government was told four months ago that the company to which it had awarded the contract was not adequate to the task. The Minister dismissed those objections and said that the right tendering procedures had been followed. He said that everything was in order and that we were simply listening to scuttlebutt and rumour mongering, but he was wrong. By any decent canon of the Westminster principle, the Minister should resign and he should not be sitting on the Government front bench. All the fancy words about departmental rearrangements, all the solid achievements of David Block-a person whom I know well, for whom I have considerable regard and who has done a good job-and all that intelligent work will be destroyed at one stroke unless, at a political level, the Prime Minister is prepared, during his third Administration, to apply the standards that he did not apply to the present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and to the former Minister for Trade, now the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), and did not apply in a number of other areas. The real test of whether the Prime Minister will be different in his third term is whether the former Minister for Transport, who clearly breached his ministerial duties over the Amann debacle and has no right to sit on the front bench of the Government, remains. If he does remain, all these great reforms will be reduced to an administrative nothing.

—Does the Treasurer agree that, for the purposes of assessing the effects of his Budget tonight on the financial markets and economy, it is the borrowing requirement which that Budget will impose upon them which is fundamental? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One can determine objectively who won the last election by those who are putting the question and those who are answering it. If we are talking about fiscal policy, the sham tax policy introduced by the Opposition in the election campaign would have, on the figuring of the Labor Opposition, reduced the Budget deficit in this year by only about $250m-that is, from its forecast $3.5 billion for 1986-87-so those honourable members opposite who are content with a Budget deficit of about $3.2 billion for 1987-88 will see how that stacks up against the Government's work.

ANSWER.PARA: That estimate was on the most charitable interpretation of the Opposition's figuring. The correct figuring would have added $2.5 billion to the Budget and in a full year about $5.5 billion, because as we on this side of the House all know, and indeed as Max Walsh pointed out so eloquently yesterday in his argument, there would have been a massive gaping hole in the deficit because the savings would never have been made. The pressure groups would have started and the internecine battles between the various interests in the coalition would have begun.

The idea of giving tax cuts now and saving later would have been exposed for the hollow sham that it is and we are indebted for the further exposure of that by the shadow Trea-surer, the honourable member for Kooyong, who last week ditched the disgraceful, shameful fiscal and tax policy of the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Mackellar proposed during the election campaign.

With that background, let me deal with that model of fiscal rectitude, the right honourable member for New England. Apparently the puny implication of the question is that assets sales should not be credited as savings against outlays. I can only make the obvious point that if the right honourable member is arguing that case he should therefore, consistently, say that if, for instance, the Government were to buy a building that should not be an addition to outlays. If he does not think that that is the case, he would be right in assuming that we are observing all the correct accounting conventions in reducing outlays by sales of government assets.

If he cavils at any contribution to the Budget from sales of government assets off outlays, all I can say is that he would then need to adjust 50 years of previous Budgets for the purchase of those assets which came from the recurrent Budgets. If the right honourable member is not arguing that, he is really arguing for a general services Budget and a capital Budget; that is, that capital items be taken off the Budget and not be funded out of recurrent budgetary revenues. If he is not arguing that but is arguing therefore that we ought to fund acquisitions and capital programs out of the Budget, it is then entirely consistent for the Government to say, as it is saying and as the accounting conventions say, that any sales of assets are proceeds to be taken off outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is he aware of the current criticism of the criteria used in the selection process of persons wishing to immigrate to Australia? Can he inform the House of the action the Government is taking to address these concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and also for the interest he has shown in this very important issue which has come before the Parliament frequently over the years. Australia is a country that can take only about 10 per cent of all those people who apply to come here; so the Parliament from time to time must lay down the criteria by which we are going to be guided as to who should or should not be allowed to come into this country. Of course, our experience is that after a period of years each system has had sufficient criticism for the government of the day to seek to revisit those criteria and review all the standards that may have been set.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been my experience over the past six or seven months-and, I am sure, that of all members in this Parliament who have a lot to do with this area-that there are some very major criticisms of the present system, particularly the concessional points system. But I sometimes find that the criticisms are quite confusing because they vary depending on the communities one meets; they all have different criticisms. It has been my view that there should be an opportunity for some of these communities, together with the Australian community in general, to sit down and discuss these matters and the criticisms which they have. As a result of my experience in this portfolio over the period leading up to the election, the Prime Minister announced the intention of the Government to produce a Green Paper on Australia's immigration policies, including the points system. I hope to be in a position early next week to announce the committee and its terms of reference.

There are a couple of matters which I should add: A couple of the basics of our immigration policy are not up for review. We are not reviewing a non-discriminatory immigration policy. The Parliament a long time ago decided that we would have a non-discriminatory policy and we are not asking for a review of that policy because I do not believe that the Parliament is seeking that. The second thing is that members continually have their views sought as to the wisdom of this Government or this Parliament agreeing to another amnesty to those people in this country illegally. On the last occasion it was the Fraser Government that declared an amnesty in Australia. It was the Fraser Government with the support of the Labor Opposition which said that that would be the last amnesty in Australia. I want to reiterate that point to the Parliament because I think that the Parliament agrees that amnesties are not the answer to an orderly immigration policy. Therefore, I want everyone to know that the question of an amnesty is not one to be reviewed by the committee and that it is not part of its terms of reference.

The other important feature of this review is that people should not think that it will be a review entirely concerning the ethnic communities in this country. This is a matter that concerns all Australians. All Australian community groups will be invited to participate by communicating to the committee, in written or verbal form, their views on the impact of migration-the numbers of migrants, the social impact and the future population projections for this country.

I believe that this matter is not just a question for the Government. The only successful immigration policy this country can have is one that has the overwhelming support of the Parliament. It will be my aim and the aim of the Government that, arising out of the review and the production of the Green Paper, the criteria laid down after this exercise will see us well through to the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I remind the Treasurer that on 17 October 1985 in this chamber he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I cannot believe that any leader of a major party would come into this Parliament and seek to have restored one of the most blatantly abused tax shelters in the system where people can minimise their income by running interest cost deductions against property. To try to defend this behaviour, this outrageous rort, on the basis that it helps some renters is extraordinary. The great majority of rental properties are not affected by negative gearing and negative gearing has not succeeded in providing an adequate number of rental properties.
I ask the Treasurer whether this is still Government policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question, of course, begs a comment on recent Press reports and the possible content of tonight's Budget, which will need to remain until then. However, let me make a few points in the abstract about costs and offsetting costs within the tax system. Let me simply say that before the introduction of capital gains tax in this country, the principle of deductions for interest was recognised by the Commissioner of Taxation on the principle that money spent in the pursuit of income was deductible. But the deductions were recognised and validated by the Commissioner on the basis that a taxable income would be brought to tax in the final analysis. Of course, as we know, under the arrangements which existed under the former Government there was no capital gains taxation and therefore all that ever happened was that there were massive losses to the revenue by the deductions of interest and costs for all manner of property, but of course, there was no taxable income because the taxpayers sold the properties off free of capital gains and realised the capital gains free of tax. That position no longer obtains in this country. It no longer obtains since the Government introduced a proper, well-constructed and thought through capital gains tax.

ANSWER.PARA: I make two further points. The Government has introduced a number of changes to the tax system which follow the general principle of offsetting deductions. The Government introduced the offsetting of group losses between companies within a group in establishing the principle that crossed deductions were entirely appropriate so long as they did not distort the shape of a company. The Government made the decision to remove the quarantining of farm income because of the problems between diffe-rentiation of on-farm and off-farm income in what were otherwise primary industry activities. Honourable members may recall that the Go-vernment published a paper prepared by the Treasury on the question of interest deductions as they relate to the acquisition of shares which came down strongly in favour of the principle that offsetting deductions should be available, particularly in the presence of a capital gains tax. I say that only by way of background because I cannot give the Deputy Leader of the Opposition an indication at this stage about the express matter he raised because it will be attended to in some way in the Budget tonight.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CITIZEN: RELEASE FROM YUGOSLAV PRISON

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the House of the detention and subsequent release of Mr Pantelich in Yugoslavia? Will he also advise whether the Government was able to contribute in some small way to the welcome outcome of that case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Pantelich is an Australian citizen of Yugoslav birth and, accordingly, has dual nationality. He was recently arrested and charged in Yugoslavia for a number of offences covering, in some cases, conduct in Australia which would not have been an offence here and, in other cases, conduct in Yugoslavia which, if it had occurred here, would not have been an offence here. The Government made vigorous representations over an extended period in defence of Mr Pantelich's rights and I was somewhat under the impression, but presumably it was an illusion, that we did contribute something towards his release. ANSWER.PARA: So I am very pleased to be able to put the record straight and to acknowledge credit where it is due. —He was probably briefed by the cab driver, and he has not paid the cab driver any of the fees. When he came back he said to the media that he saw senior members, anonymously described, of the Yugoslav Government-the Assistant Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Assistant Minister for Justice. In fact I will tell the House whom he did see: he saw an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, at assistant secretarial level; he saw an official of the same sort of level in the Federal Secretariat for Justice; he saw an official of the US Embassy; he saw the Serbian Orthodox priest; and he saw Pantelich's lawyer. The honourable member for North Sydney is the one who complained to the Australian mission in Belgrade that the level of officials he saw was far inferior to that which he expected to see, given his status. What he is saying by implication is that, if he was to be taken seriously and be influential, the status of the people he saw and the officials with whom he dealt was far less than was appropriate. Without making this relevant to the particular case, all I can say is that there are ways of conveying diplomatic messages, and I think this may have been one. If he says that the status of these people was less than appropriate in order for him to exercise influence in these matters, it is marvellous that he alone was able to bring about this result.

ANSWER.PARA: So the mild-mannered honourable member for North Sydney wishes to be the Clark Kent of the Australian Parliament. Clark Kent used to pop out from behind telephone booths. The honourable member for North Sydney leaps out from behind the occasional international airline ticket to complain selectively about particular matters. He has not complained about the plight of Miss Gillian Bertwistle, who faces a quite outrageous situation in Greece. The Australian Government is handling that. He has not complained, as far as I can see, about the plight of George and Hannah Holec and their baby. This Czechoslovak couple came to Australia and are now seeking a reuniting with their infant. The Australian Government is making representations on these matters, and no doubt, after they are all over, presuming we are successful, we will again labour under the misapprehension that we did it all by ourselves. We will then discover that the honourable member sent a letter to the respective capital cities of the countries where these problems have arisen and fixed them all up. The fact is that the Australian Government made representations on this matter effectively over a long period and the intrusion of the honourable member for North Sydney in the initial stages put Mr Pantelich's situation in grave peril.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister give an unequivocal guarantee to the House that personal information on Australian citizens to be stored in the Government's identity card computer system will be totally secure from interference, leakage and publication?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I observe that over recent times there has been an extraordinary number of unfounded allegations about the lack of security that will attach to the data associated with the Australia Card. Let me make it clear, Madam Speaker, that there will be no leakage, release of information of the sort that is referred to in the question by the Leader of the Opposition. I make it quite clear that there will be no secret files containing personal information on Australia Card subjects. It should be understood that individuals will have access to all information about themselves, including access to information relating to program management of their card. That will be free of charge once a year.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Card Register will contain only basic identifying data such as name, address, postal address, date of birth, sex, whether permanent or non-permanent resident and digitised photograph and signature as well as the administrative details necessary to assist the authority in the management of the program. That will be limited to such things as where and when such cards were issued, details of any replacement cards and details of amendments made to information held on the Register. Knowledge of the structure of the Australia Card database would be absolutely useless to so-called hackers without an ability to access that database. This will be prevented by a range of security and protection measures which include non-transmission of information via public telephone lines which could be intercepted by unauthorised users, the encryption of all data transmissions, thereby making the information meaningless in the unlikely event that it were intercepted. Also, sophisticated security software will be used to control and record access, to authorise inquiries and to update the Register. There will be no other computers linked to the Australia Card Register. The only access will be through terminals connected to a dedicated communications network. In those and in other ways there will be total security of the information associated with the Australia Card. I repeat, as I said before the House resumed, that this Government remains committed to proceed with the implementation of the Australia Card because it is the only system of integrity which will ensure bringing an end to the tax cheats and the welfare frauds and bringing in a net $1 billion almost to the public revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories been drawn to the stories and editorials in today's Courier-Mail and Daily Sun concerning the Queensland Government's decision to allow Imperial Chemical Industries (ICI) Australia to build a caustic chlorine plant on a property previously owned by the Commonwealth in the Brisbane suburb of Lytton, which is in my electorate of Bowman? Is the Commonwealth Government satisfied that all environmental safeguards and studies have been met in regard to this proposal given the Queensland Government's sudden turnaround on the issue after the Federal election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bowman for his question, the level of which I am sure will be typical of the honourable member's future career in this House. I am aware of the reports in today's Press in Queensland about the irresponsible decision made by the Queensland Premier. Yes, I am concerned, as the honourable member is, about first of all the environmental difficulties posed by this proposition and also the danger to the health of people living in Lytton which, I might tell honourable members, is in the metropolitan residential area near the mouth of the Brisbane River. The Lytton industrial site is only 1 1/2 kilometres from large residential estates. The proposition would never have been allowed if it had come under the purview of the Commonwealth Act-the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Unfortunately, that is not the case. In what is a typical, cavalier, Queensland fashion, the Premier is railroading this decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The only environmental impact study was conducted by ICI, the proponent of the plant. No independent study of the effects of the proposition has been put into place. The environmental impact study is certainly inadequate. In an article in the Daily Sun on 31 August it was admitted that there were serious risks associated with this project. No consideration has been given to alternative proposals or alternative sites. As I understand it, Denison Resources, a local Australian-owned company, is proposing to build a much bigger chlorine plant in Blackall, way out in the sticks. That has not been allowed. ICI, a multinational company, has been given this extraordinary permission to build the plant in Brisbane. The Deputy Premier, Mr Gunn, has even offered an alternative site in his own electorate of Somerset, which is west of Brisbane. Of course, he has also been denied that opportunity.

The honourable member made a very good point. In the Federal election period the matter was pushed aside. People were told, `Don't you worry about that.' But now that the election is over, the Premier has made this irresponsible decision to put this chlorine plant in a residential area. He has alienated his own Party. Sir Robert Sparkes has distanced himself from the proposition. Even the Minister for Industry and Technology, Mr McKechnie, who is in no way a genius, has said, `It is not politically acceptable to have the plant on Lytton Industrial Estate'. How right he is.

This is a disgraceful decision that has been made by an arrogant and increasingly senile Queensland Premier. It is no wonder that the Australian Labor Party now holds more than half the seats in Queensland. All of the characters opposite who represent fairly marginal seats in Queensland should have a serious look at the behaviour of their Premier, because on this occasion he has certainly exceeded any reasonable bounds in allowing this proposal to go through. It is a deplorable decision to allow an industrial proposition of this type to be built in such a position. It will pose grave environmental dangers. More importantly, it poses great risks to the health of the people living nearby. The quicker that this decision is reversed by the Queensland National Party, and the quicker that the Queensland Premier, increasingly stupid as he is, is made to retract, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. What is the difference between a normal Telecom Australia line and the `landline' that Senator Ryan and, now, the Prime Minister say will be used to interconnect the various computers and computer terminals that will carry confidential information accessible by the ID card number? Is the line referred to by Senator Ryan and the Prime Minister in fact a dedicated Telecom line? Will this line still require linkage through Telecom exchanges? Would such a line be more easily identified by interested persons because of its dedicated status? Can the Minister guarantee the absolute security of such a connection in light of recent evidence of phone tapping?

—I am happy to answer this question. In fact, I am delighted that the honourable member for O'Connor was the first person to address a question to me. I think that it shows a degree of concern on his part, which I appreciate. However, the question was of such a detailed nature that I intend to go away, do my homework and get a very detailed reply for him, so that all the technical details can be taken into account and I can provide him with all the details that he wants. I am sure that the people of Australia would want a detailed reply to that sort of question, and not a simple off-the-cuff answer.
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. There are 16 million Australians wanting this answer.
—Order! The honourable member will sit down. It is not a point of order and he knows it.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of the widespread concern in the veteran community following a recent Federal Court of Australia decision on the entitlements of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans over the age of 65? Can he advise the House what action the Government intends to take to ensure that elderly TPI veterans do not lose their disability pensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the honourable member for Dobell has asked me my maiden question. I can assure honourable members that he is a very hard-working and dedicated member of this Parliament. Actually, he sent me a telegram on the very issue on which he has asked a question.
—Will you put it on notice?

—I do not intend to put it on notice. I am certainly aware of the widespread concern in the veteran community and the widespread concern of all honourable members on both sides of the chamber, especially the honourable member for Farrer, who is now shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister. I had the pleasure of addressing the executive committee of TPI pensioners in Canberra and I was informed in no uncertain circumstances that if we did not fix up the problem pensioners would be marching on Parliament House with fixed bayonets. I can assure honourable members that I was very concerned about that so I reported the matter to the Prime Minister. I must say also how appreciative I am of the support I have received in the Cabinet on this very issue.

ANSWER.PARA: The recent Federal Court decision threw into doubt the entitlements of TPI and intermediate rate pensions to be paid for life by implying that veterans might cease to be entitled once they passed the retiring age. I am pleased to say that the Prime Minister announced the Government's decision at the Returned Services League national conference on 31 August 1987. The Government will not allow the Federal Court's interpretation of the new Veterans' Entitlements Act to stand. An amendment to the legislation will be introduced in the Parliament as soon as possible so as to ensure that TPI and intermediate rate pensions, once granted, continue to be payable indefinitely, except where there is evidence of fraud, a significant improvement in health or a resumption of employment. The Government's decision reflects a strong commitment to ensuring that the veterans receive what is due to them as compensation for their services to the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--

—I am a great favourite of the Australian Labor Party! I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to the penalty provisions of the identity card legislation and remind him that, under the legislation, if someone employing a baby-sitter fails to pass the baby-sitter's identification card number to the Australian Taxation Office, the employer of the baby-sitter will be fined the incredible amount of $20,000. Why has the Government chosen absurd and draconian penalties of this kind to enforce legislation which is, in itself, a major threat to civil liberties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo may not know that under the existing taxation laws there are significant penalties for not reporting in these matters. In minor matters, such as baby-sitting and housekeeping, the tax laws have always behaved in a tolerant way.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ah!

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply repeat for all members of the Opposition that they should go back and read the laws that presently exist in these areas. The reason that there are penalties in the present tax laws and penalties in the Australia Card law is to deal with significant cases of abuse. If there is significant abuse the penalties are available. When honourable members on that side of the House are not fantasising for the public they know that these issues have always been matters of administrative discretion. As under the present tax laws they are matters of administrative discretion so under the Australia Card law they will be matters of administrative discretion.

—Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of claims by the Australian Privacy Foundation that there will be a secret section of the Australia Card Register? Can the Minister inform the House as to the accuracy of such a claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The allegation that there would be a secret file on the Australia Card Register is simply another kind of fantasy, another kind of alarm that people seek to spread about the Australia Card. We saw a moment ago an effort to blow up a minor matter of tax administration into the same order. There would be no secret file containing personal information on the Australia Card Register. It seems that the Privacy Foundation in New South Wales, which apparently is the source of this latest fantasy, has discovered after reading the legislation for some 12 months-it has been around for something like 12 months-that under sub-clause 25 (2) of the Australia Card Bill the Health Insurance Commission may include on the Australia Card Register such information as is reasonably necessary for the efficient performance of its function, and by that is meant recording on the Register such things as the time a card was issued and any lost card and report of that. In order to have an efficient administration of the program those program management points would be made on the Register. Of course, all that information is available to the person to whom the card relates. So it is possible for a person to get that information, automatically once a year or at some other stage, if he or she requires it, for a small fee. Nothing on the Register is on a secret file. It is all openly available to the card subjects themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: I also point out that the material on the Australia Card Register is the sort of identifying material that most Australians provide at least once a month to some private or public bureaucracy. They fill in a form once a month. It is rare for Australians during a month not to have to fill in some identifying information such as their name, address, and date and place of birth. That is the basic material contained on the Australia Card Register plus the management details to which I have just referred, both of which are available to any card subject who wishes to get that information.

In addition, there are further protections to that Register. Under the Act, the logging of any access by any bureaucrat to that Register is recorded and that information too will be available to the individual. As the Prime Minister pointed out, there is the use of sophisticated security software to control and log that access so that no bureaucrat can make those inquiries without his name and that of the agency turning up on the Register so that people can get that information. That should make a much better provision of security about government files than anything previously offered in this country. Finally, as the Prime Minister has pointed out, extra security devices such as the scrambling of the information to prevent unauthorised access will be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question on behalf of Australia Card subjects, and it is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Will he advise the House how Australia's 650,000 small businesses can authenticate the cards presented by new employees so as to avoid the $20,000 fine and keep to their statutory obligations? How is it to be done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: this is a matter related to small businesses. Why is the Minister for Community Services and Health answering?

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Minister will decide which questions he answers. The matter is not to do with the honourable member for O'Connor or with the Chair. It is a matter for the Minister. May I point out that, as well as Party leaders being vigilant in ensuring that the Chair is fair and impartial, they should also ensure that their members behave with decorum in the House.

—Madam Speaker, with the greatest of respect, may I say to you that, to start off the proceedings of the new Parliament, just because there has been a vigorous exchange between the Government and the Opposition and just because they do not--

—Order! I am making it clear as we start off the new Parliament that I appreciated your comments yesterday. I believe that you have a responsibility to be vigilant about what the Chair does. However, there is an equal responsibility on the three party leaders to ensure that the Chair is not continually ignored when asking that members cease interjections, and that goes for both sides of the House.

—Madam Speaker, I have absolutely no argument with that as a matter of principle, but the use of that admonition at this stage of the proceedings implies that in some way the Opposition has not been behaving correctly or with decorum. I will say, with the greatest respect to you Madam Speaker, that I do not accept one iota of that admonition.
—The honourable member may not accept it, nevertheless the admonition is for all members of the House.

—The question asked by the honourable member for Gippsland related to the authentication of cards by small business employers. That is very much a task which falls within the Australia Card program, so it is appropriate that I answer the question. It also gives me the opportunity to deal with another misconception about this matter which has been spread widely. First, the only task of the employer is to request a card and a card number. If that is given it is a responsibility of the employer to provide that information when he provides other details of tax to the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.PARA: If the employee does not produce a card to the employer all that the employer is required to do is take out tax at the top rate so that the tax system is secure. He is not required to get a number from a person who refuses to give a number. There are other sanctions to protect the income tax system in those situations. If the employer, for instance, is given a forged card or forged number the responsibility rests with the employee, not the employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the House of the attitude of the Australian Government to the recent referendum on independence conducted in New Caledonia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The referendum which was held in New Caledonia over the weekend was certainly held according to principles stipulated by the French administration. Whether it will be regarded as an authentic expression of the aspirations of a pluralistic society is yet to be established. My inclination is that pressures from the independence movement within New Caledonia, the Kanak movement, will continue to be manifested not in spite of but because of the outcome of this referendum. The referendum was altogether too stark in the alternatives it offered: either to remain with France or to be cast adrift.

ANSWER.PARA: The referendum held by France on 13 September was also inconsistent with the requirements of the United Nations for the processes for decolonisation as laid down by the Committee of Twenty-four. It was inconsistent for these reasons: co-operation with the United Nations was refused; there was no political education regarding the options; there was no dialogue among various parties; the choice was restricted, as I mentioned, to two quite stark options; punitive consequences were implicitly, and occasionally explicitly, attached to the independence option; and the French Government campaigned hard for its preferred option, continued attachment to France. A new statute has been foreshadowed following the referendum but the form of that statute has not been elaborated by the French Government.

It seems unlikely that the conflicting positions of the two principal bodies of opinion in the territory will be changed by the referendum. This is a matter of direct concern to the Australian Government. It concerns matters which arise in our immediate region of interest, a region in which we prefer to see stability and amity. We sincerely trust that these problems can be sorted out. We believe that they would have been sorted out satisfactorily if the earlier Fabius and Pisani plans, which provided for an option of independence in association with France, had been proceeded with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition presenting forthwith an Australia Card Referendum Bill 1987 which, in conjunction with an amendment to be moved to the Australia Card Bill 1986, will require the proposed introduction of an Australia Card to be submitted to, and approved by, a referendum of the Australian people.

There are five reasons why, in my view and in the view of the Opposition, this motion to suspend Standing Orders to permit me as Leader of the Opposition to introduce immediately an Australia Card Referendum Bill should be accepted by this House. It is perfectly clear to anybody in this Parliament and anybody observing this Parliament as a media commentator, as a card subject or, as I prefer it, as an Australian citizen, from today's Question Time that an identity card-and I will not dignify it until and unless I am forced by parliamentary procedure to do so with the description `Australia Card', which is a disgraceful use of the name of our nation to give the card some kind of cheap bipartisan dignity-is being rejected more and more every day by the majority of Australian people.

All I can say to the Government is that if it believes the result of the last election was evidence that the majority of the Australian people support the proposed identity card, it is totally and completely deluding itself. The Government knows as well as I do that there is growing disquiet within its ranks about this legislation. The Government knows that groups that would normally support the Australian Labor Party on other issues are turning against the Labor party on this particular matter. But, worse than that, the Government knows that even if the legislation were to pass a joint sitting of this Parliament, ahead of the Government is 18 months or two years of absolute political purgatory in getting the Australia Card mechanism established. The Government knows that ahead of it over the next 18 months or two years there will be a series of guerrilla attacks; there will be warfare waged against the identity card legislation by those in the community who are totally opposed to it.

It is worth reminding the House that in October of last year, when the Liberal and National parties in this Parliament decided to oppose the identity card legislation, our stand at that time was criticised by not only the Government but just about every major media outlet in the country. The conventional wisdom at that time was that the identity card legislation was a very good idea.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still is.

—Of course, the honourable member's opinion that it is still a good idea stands very much alone. I wonder whether that view is shared by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). I ask the honourable member for Calare whether he remembers what has been said by the honourable member for Hotham, who sits on the Government benches behind the Ministers who have introduced this legislation. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I reject the necessity for the introduction of the card. That it is called the Australia Card is an exercise in cynicism in itself. Nothing can be more un-Australian than the need to prove one's identity on the call of an official, be it a politician or a bureaucrat.

Those are not the words of a Liberal or National Party member of parliament-although every one of us on this side would echo those sentiments. I remind honourable members opposite that they are the words of the honourable member for Hotham-one of their colleagues. Honourable members know darned well that this issue is causing very deep divisions within their own ranks. They know that they have sold their own supporters a bill of goods on this issue. They know that when it was pushed through the Parliament in October and November of last year-when we in the Liberal and National parties almost alone with the Australian Democrats came out against the card-they thought they had everybody on their side.

The Australian newspaper, in its editorial, criticised our stand against the card, saying that it was a far from brilliant move from the electoral point of view. That editorial said that it was a decision that would backfire. It said that we were behaving like the friends of tax avoiders. The Sydney Morning Herald said that we were being too clever by half. Most of the political correspondents in the Federal Press Gallery came out against our stand. That was 10 months ago. Now, in September 1987, the stand that we took then has been vindicated.

Honourable members opposite only have to move around their electorates to see that is so. Honourable members opposite know, as well as do our own members, that they have lost the Australian public on the subject of the identity card. If the Government thinks that it can go ahead with this identity card in the teeth of mounting public opposition, if it really believes that it can introduce an identity card that no other common law nation in the world has introduced, if it believes that it can ram down the throats of the Australian public draconian penalties of between $20,000 and $100,000 for not properly reporting employment details, if it really believes it can introduce an identification database that will expose every Australian citizen to a potential invasion of privacy such as we have never before seen in this country, if the Government believes that it can get away with that-it really has totally lost touch with reality.

The truth is that the great bulk of Government members know, deep down that, they are not on a winner with this issue and that the public is against it. We are saying to the Government: put aside all this phoney nonsense about mandates. If the Government really believes, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) keeps telling us, that the great majority of the Australian people want an identity card, if it really believes that it is in the interests of the Australian public to have an ID card and if it really believes that it will collect $1,000m of evaded tax by introducing an ID card, why does it not have a referendum? Why do we not go to the Australian public and have a clear, unvarnished vote? If the Government is so confident of its ground, why do we not have a vote on this issue and on this issue alone? The only reason that the Government is not prepared to accept that is that it knows that if it had a vote on the card it would lose overwhelmingly. The Government's smear campaign on the identity card has not worked. The Government is very good at running a smear campaign. It operates on the simple principle that if somebody disagrees with what it intends to do that person is either a crook or a tax cheat.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—The honourable member for Calare says, `That's right'. Everybody who was opposed to negative gearing was either a crook or a tax cheat. Yet tonight negative gearing is to be brought back. We know why it is being brought back. It is being brought back because Barrie Unsworth wants it brought back. It has absolutely nothing to do with tax morality or anything else. The same situation applies with the identity card. If a person is against the identity card it is not that he does not have legitimate privacy concerns and a legitimate concern about the size of government and that he does not genuinely believe that it may be possible to collect all of the evaded tax by using existing methods and procedures. No! If a person is against the identity card he is, ipso facto, as far as the Government is concerned, a crook or a tax cheat. I have to say to Government members that, according to their definition, there must be millions of crooks and tax cheats in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: By any measure of any politician with any experience, the majority of the Australian people have turned against the identity card. If the Prime Minister and Government members doubt our assessment of this, if they really believe that the Australian people have bought their argument about people opposing the card being the friends of tax dodgers, why do they not put that belief to a test at a referendum and not hide behind the argument that there is some kind of mandate out of the last election? That suggestion is invalid not only in terms of the number of votes cast but also on the simple proposition that when people vote at an election they do not vote on only one issue. The mandate theory of politics from the point of view of proper analysis has always been absolutely phoney.

The one thing that would not be phoney would be if this Government had the guts to submit this proposal to a referendum. That is why there is urgency. It is clear from public concern and the atmosphere in the House today that the No. 1 political issue in Australia at present is the Government's ID card. The only way to resolve the issue and the only way, ultimately, to accept the judgment of the Australian people is for us to submit it to a referendum. If the Government is so sure of its ground, if it believes that it can nail us with the smear of being friends of tax avoiders and tax cheats, why does it not have the courage to take the proposal to a referendum? It will not do so because it knows that it would be overwhelmingly beaten.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. The motion calls for the suspension of Standing Orders so that we can introduce a Bill to ensure that the whole question of the identity card will be subjected to proper scrutiny by the Australian people and that there be a vote by the Australian people. Why is the Government running scared? Barrie Unsworth now recognises that the card is no good. We know the left wing's views and we have heard the comments of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) on the card. They think that the card is no good. The Australian Council of Trade Unions and a very substantive majority of the Australian electorate thinks that it is no good.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three basic reasons why we see it essential that this measure go, by way of a private member's Bill, to a referendum to ensure that the Australian electorate at large can vote on whether or not there should be an identity card. Without any doubt the first is that the identity card proposal breaches the fundamental privacy of every Australian citizen. `Card subjects', we heard the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) call Australian people during Question Time. The Special Minister of State, Senator Susan Ryan, has said as far as privacy is concerned that messages through the computers will go into some sort of dedicated Telecom line so that they will not be subject to hackers. She can tell us that one again. Quite obviously, the very nature of the transfer of computer data involves the use of ordinary communications in such a way that they can be accessed. We all know the degree to which that happens. So in terms of privacy there is absolutely no doubt that the rights and privileges of ordinary Australians will be prejudiced by this legislation.

The second quite fundamental reason it is necessary that Standing Orders be suspended and that we have a Bill to ensure that before the identity card proposal becomes law there is a referendum is the penalties within the legislation. We had a very interesting Question Time today. There were a series of questions to various Ministers, including some who were not allowed to answer. The poor old Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones)--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer won't let him answer and now the Minister for Community Services and Health won't let him answer.

—The Treasurer (Mr Keating) will not let him answer anything to do with science and nothing to do with prices, and we found out today that he is not even allowed to answer anything in respect of small business. The poor old muted Minister for Science and Small Business has obscured the whole problem. If one is a small businessman or, as my colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) put it, somebody employing a child minder to care for his children, unless he asks the employee to produce an identity card he might be subject to a penalty of up to $20,000.

SPEECH.PARA: If an employer hires a cardless person, he or she can be fined up to $20,000. We should remember that that is the maximum penalty, but the person can also be gaoled as a result of not paying the fine. What will this Government do to thousands of ordinary Australians conducting their ordinary affairs around the country? It will gaol them if they do not produce their ID cards. So the second reason it is essential to have a referendum is the penalties-the obnoxious character of the penalties, the degree to which they intrude on the ordinary affairs of Australians and the extent to which they are grossly excessive. The card will impose undue obligations on the way in which the ordinary men and women of this country conduct their affairs.

The third and quite fundamental reason we see it as essential that this Bill be allowed introduction and passage is that the cost benefit analysis, as revealed by the committee examination of the whole proposal before it was introduced, shows that the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and all his Ministers are totally deluding the Australian people in terms of the benefits that are supposed to result from it. We all know that it is not designed to cover in any way tax rorts or social welfare fraud; the whole concept is really to regiment the Australian society. There will be 2,000 more public servants. We know that the cost of introduction will continue until the first time the card can be applied, which we understand is three or four years hence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the arguments put forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), and I am not persuaded to adopt the course they offer. The slightest pressure sends him racing to the airport to see Joh, John Elliott or somebody else, in order to try to keep the ship of state together, because he has always crumbled. I continually hope and pray that honourable members opposite observe and analyse their politics in the same way that they have done since 11 July. For God's sake, do not blame the Leader of the Opposition for anything that took place on 11 July. Leave him there forever. That will ensure the continuation of a Labor government in this country for a long time. The Leader of the Opposition cannot even handle the pressures of his shadow Ministry. He has to try to juggle things among the wets, the dries and the States. He has no strength or guts. He crumbles all the time. He is unable to reach the level of political leadership that is needed in this country. Of course, as he said on 11 and 12 July, `If it weren't for Joh, I'd be Prime Minister'. Poor old Joh! He jumped on a plane, went to see Joh, came back and told the Parliament, `Joh and I have a lot in common. We're going down the same path. We're going round the corner and down the path.
