Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duncan,Mr Jull,Mr Kerin and Mr Lindsay.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Peacock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned draw to the attention of the House of Representatives our concern at any change to the Australian Flag without first holding a Referendum to assess the opinion of the citizens of Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to make no changes to the Australian Flag without reference to the citizens of Australia in the form of a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively sheweth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action nor permit any action to be taken to make any change without the approval of the Australian people by referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr N.A. Brown,Mr Cunningham and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Member of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respect- fully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Millar.

PETITION.TITLE: Two Dollar Coin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Member of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That, as a consequence of the Hawke Government's decision to introduce a two dollar coin in 1988,

Whereas the introduction of a one dollar coin was only a twofold increase in the maximum value of coinage, the elimination of the two dollar note represents a five-fold increase before a note can be used

It will have taken eighteen years from decimalisation to go from the fifty cent piece as the highest value coin to a one dollar coin, but only a further four years to replace the two dollar note with a coin
The lowest value paper note will be five dollars, forcing a dramatic increase in the weight of coinage carried and dislocation of the retail industry
Many people, particularly the elderly, will mistake the value of the coin for that of another lower value coin just as many now confuse a one dollar coin with the ten cent piece

That the addition of the two new coins in four years will lead to the removal of the one cent and two cent coins and this will accelerate the cost of living, particularly the cost of food where numerous items are involved and future price rises would need to be five cent increases on every item on every occasion.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the proposed two dollar coin not be proceeded with by the Hawke Government, and no future Government proceed with this proposal for several years.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned by the threat to social morality and the welfare of children, posed by the unrestricted importation, distribution and sale of X-rated pornographic video material in and from the Australian Capital Territory.

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should recognise our concern and reverse its amendments to ACT legislation and Customs regulations which have resulted in Australia wide distribution of material restricted under State censorship laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Langmore and Mr Snow.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T. in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and its availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography peddlers are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Adult Migrant Education Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned strongly protest 1987 cuts to ESL programs for adults, conducted by the Adult Migrant Education Service (AMES) in New South Wales.
Evening ESL classes have been cut by 25%.
The ESL Correspondence course is to be abolished in a few months time.
The English-in-the-Workplace Program has been reduced.
Full-time on-arrival courses have been abolished.
AMES day centres have had their teaching hours reduced.
Community programs have lost teaching hours.
We call for-
(i) the full and immediate restoration of AMES teaching programs in New South Wales to at least 1986 levels and
(ii) a substantial increase in funding to AMES programs in the 1987 budget, in view of the recently announced increases in the immigration intake.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Webster and Mr Uren.

PETITION.TITLE: Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the intention of the Hawke Government to unionise independent contractors, sub-contractors, the self-employed, partnerships, sole traders and family businesses will remove the freedom of independent small business to-
(a) set their own prices
(b) work their own hours
(c) control their own businesses
(d) negotiate their own contracts;
and will create impossible working conditions which will include the payment of-
(a) union superannuation
(b) compensation
(c) payroll tax
(d) annual leave loadings
(e) public holiday loadings
(f) PAYE tax deductions
(g) limited incomes
(h) inflexible awards and conditions; and
(i) fixed hours of work.
We the undersigned call upon the Government to restore incentive and opportunity to the Australian economy and to abandon these coercive measures.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatrists
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Podiatrists are primary contact health practitioners, and as such require the highest standard of education.

2. The panel appears to be ill-informed about current podiatric practice, not only in Australia but throughout the world. The majority of recent graduates world-wide enjoy degree status, and Australian graduates should not be pegged to a standard lower than that of their overseas counterparts.

3. Considerable advances have been made in the field of podiatry, as well as associated medical sciences. Degree level education should be the minimum requirement for the analysis and evaluation of findings required in these fields, and to enable proper application to the needs of the patients.

4. From the industrial point of view, any health practitioner who has his qualifications downgraded will be severely disadvantaged in terms of reward for labour. Moreover, the practitioner's respect and credibility in the eyes of the other health practitioners will be reduced.

5. The panel was required to be constructed of independent members according to its own terms of reference, yet the panel consists of two medical practitioners out of a total of three. This could amount to one profession sitting in judgment of another.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the above decision and recommendation are not implemented.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Arms Race
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600. We your petitioners, humbly showeth:
That Australia is passively contributing to the escalation of the nuclear arms race and its misdirection of financial and human resources by allowing:
The stationing of foreign military bases that deny our national sovereignty and have an aggressive first strike nuclear capability.

The visits of nuclear armed and powered warships which have an active role in any nuclear war, and the potential for disastrous accidents whilst in port, which could never be covered by adequate port safety plans.
The mining and export of uranium, which cannot be adequately safeguarded against being used in nuclear weapons, and testing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House disengage Australia from the nuclear arms race by removing all foreign military bases from Australia; halting the visits of nuclear powered and armed warships of any foreign power; banning the mining and export of uranium, except for medical use.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Pain, suffering and death are occurring as a result of the action of sections of the medical profession and private health insurance companies.
People are being forced into private health funds and denied treatment until they do so.
We call on the Government to take action against these doctors and private health insurance companies who are engaging in this practice.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: R-rated Video Movies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That the undersigned believe freedom of thought, expression and choice is in jeopardy by the action of minority groups, to ban the sale and hire of video movies with a rating of ``R'' classification notwithstanding that such ``R'' movies could be shown at cinemas and on television.
2. That examples of titles of video movies with ``R'' classification include such well known movies as:
``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' (Jack Nicholson)
``First Blood'' and ``Cobra'' (Sylvester Stallone)
``Dirty Harry'' and ``Sudden Impact'' (Clint Eastwood)
(`Make my day!')
``Midnight Express''
``The Godfather''
``Apocalypse Now'' (Marlon Brando)
``Crimes of Passion'' (Kathleen Turner & Anthony Perkins)
``Mad Max'' (Mel Gibson)
``The Deer Hunter'' (Robert DeNiro & Meryl Streep)

3. That we the undersigned believe that very little thought has been given to the devastating consequences of the economic impact on the video retailing industry of banning the sale and hire of ``R'' rated movies.
4. That we the undersigned are concerned video library members, all over the age of 18 years, many of whom are parents who believe that they should retain certain basic freedoms namely:
(a) the right to view video movies of their own individual choice and not that imposed by Governments or minority groups;
(b) The right to exercise their own discretion and control over their own childrens' viewing habits in lieu of the control sought to be imposed by Governments and minority groups.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that all legislation proposed to the banning of the sale of hire ``R'' classification video movies be immediately stayed pending:
(a) an informed public debate on an issue which in essence involves freedom of thought, expression and choice; and
(b) a thorough review is made of the economic impact of banning ``R'' classified movies on the video retail industry.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal;
Is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud,
Will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter,
Will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the tax payer, and
Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives.
The petition of the undersigned do respectfully showeth that pornographic material relating to children is deleterious to the health and welfare of children and society as a whole.
We respectfully urge the Government to ban all child pornography from entering or from being produced in Australia.
And your petitioners, in duty-bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards-
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilizing nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to out space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(A) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapons states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time, (B) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal Members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginals in Custody
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
In respect of Aboriginals in custody in Australia.
1. Their numbers in custody, as compared to the size of their population, are disproportionate to the number in custody in relationship to the rest of the community, by a factor of ten to one.
2. There are numerous Aboriginal deaths in custody.
3. Coronial inquiries into such deaths often return either verdicts of deaths by misadventure, heart attack or open verdicts.
4. Most often no blame or criticism is directed against the persons in custodial authority, despite the fact that they are the sole persons in attendance prior to and at the time of death.
5. Many of the deaths are associated with acts of violence and brutality, and often the deceased goes through a period of physical and mental suffering which is unrelieved by any medical treatment.
We believe that the custodial systems as aforesaid are urgently in need of review and change. We call on the legislature to appoint a Federal Royal Commission for this purpose.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Gungahlin Road, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we consider the proposal by the NCDC to construct a road along the eastern boundary of the National Botanic Gardens, adjoining CSIRO, to be detrimental to the area's ecology and to the peaceful enjoyment of nature, which the Gardens presently provide.

We consider also that the proposed road, which is intended as a link to the new town of Gungahlin, increases the spoilation of the eastern side of Black Mountain, and its foothills, Bruce Ridge and O'Connor Ridge to the north, thus detracting from the amenity of the area and from the important bushland backdrop visible from inner north Canberra, which is the gateway to Canberra for many of its visitors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(a) The proposed road, along the National Botanic Gardens-CSIRO boundary and along the eastern side of Black Mountain and its foothills, be not built.
(b) Alternative measures for access to Gungahlin be implemented instead.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with mismanagement of the Otway forests in Victoria, and we pray that:
The constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant public expressions of concern, e.g. petitions by some action, e.g. referendums or committees of inquiry.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until August 6 this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Government's Australia Card will be an attack on the civil liberties and privacy of all Australians, will not achieve the claimed results, will provide a boost to organised crime and will be an enormous burden to the private sector, especially small business, already snowed under with government charges, taxes and red tape.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to abandon legislation for any type of national identity system and work toward building a society based on trust not suspicion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fire and Ambulance Services, Woomera, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, actions of the Administration at the Defence Support Centre, Woomera, to disband the permanent Professional Fire and Ambulance Services currently provided and replace them with paid volunteer personnel.
Your petitioners therefore pray that, the permanent Professional Fire and Ambulance Services remain for the protection and security of the citizens of Woomera.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to show restraint with equity. In particular, the decision to defer the November pension adjustments has resulted in a loss of $25.62 for a single pensioner and $21.36 for each married pensioner.
The prospect of a further deferral of the May adjustment will result in the loss of another $35.10 for a single pensioner and $29.10 for each married pensioner.

When you are scrimping to make ends meet, as is the case with many pensioners, you can't afford such a cut in living standards. Pensioners are looking for a new deal from politicians-more of the same is not good enough!
Your petitioners request an immediate return to payment of May and November C.P.I. increases, and as is duty bound will ever pray the Government grant this request now.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament call upon the Video Committee to release its recommendations to ban violent and damaging videos forthwith, and desist with the plan to re-impose X rated videos in all states wherein they have been banned. We entreat that the ACT be brought into line with other states in the banning of X rated videos, and that the Committee be not allowed to further delay its findings until after the polls. Because we have waited for a long-time, patiently, but are becoming alarmed over their evidence, p2770, 3008 and 2989, 2990, and call upon Parliament to end the Canberra connections.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance Payments and Dependent Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
The costs of raising children are rising and the value of government provided economic assistance to families is declining.
Families raising children are providing a vital function to society and are deserving of government provided economic assistance.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
1. Restore family allowance payments to their 1976 real money value.
2. Provide for the regular and automatic indexation of family allowance payments.
3. Increase the value of the Dependent Spouse Rebate to $1851 per annum, and convert it to a cash payment given directly to the non-income earning spouse.
4. Amend the Family Income Supplement Scheme so that its value is increased, its eligibility provisions widened and its withdrawal provisions eased.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words: ``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conditions of Service and Remuneration for Servicemen
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that serving members of the Australian Defence Forces are frustrated and disillusioned at the continuing erosion of their conditions of employment, benefits and entitlements traditionally provided in recognition of the burden placed on themselves and their families by service in the Defence Forces;

2. that the Government's decision to discount by 2 per cent the retirement benefits of members of the Australian Defence Forces has broken a trust that should exist between servicemen and the Government concerning the financial security of themselves and their families in retirement;

3. that the Government's decision to discount the retirement benefits of members of the Australian Defence Forces has seriously lowered the morale and commitment of servicemen and will further increase the number of experienced servicemen leaving the Defence Forces.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you establish or expedite reviews of conditions, salary, allowances, entitlements and benefits for servicemen and reverse the decision to discount by 2% retirement benefits for servicemen.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that;

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to repeal its anti-business, anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
1. the effect of present Government policy in not returning a fairer share of road taxes and fuel excise to the community for road construction and maintenance is totally iniquitous; and
2. unless immediate action is taken to redress this funding situation, our road network will disintegrate beyond reasonable repair.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully request that Road Funding be increased to a level that will arrest the constant deterioration of the road system and enable roads and streets such as Sutton Street, between Sebastopol and Delacombe to be reconstructed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House, the Federal Government's proposal to legislate in favour of the introduction of the I.D. Australia Card.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will vote against this legislation, and oppose it with every means at your disposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Accommodation, Maitland, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned senior citizens and pensioners indicate that they are gravely concerned at the inadequate nursing home accommodation in the local government area of Maitland. We urgently request the establishment of an Allandale type nursing hospital in our area.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Wealth Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Gwydir electorate respectfully:

Condemn the Hawke Labor Government's high tax policies and state our total opposition to the introduction of any new taxes including a wealth tax on the net wealth of individual Australians and Australian business.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to not introduce an investment destroying wealth tax into the House of Representatives.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the people of the Upper Hunter. Respectfully showeth their concern regarding the proposal by Telecom to meter local calls.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House be aware of the immeasurable psychological damage this proposal will cause as it will inhibit the user because of the cost incurred, and we call on Telecom to abandon this proposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell uranium to France.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Prime Minister to heed or explain adequately the legitimate concerns of the Australian people regarding the effects and effectiveness of the Australia Card.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
That the business of the day be called on.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure and to have it incorporated in Hansard. I would like to say to the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) that the Government has looked at the recommendation of the Committee and that he will see from the report I am tabling that we do not accept the recommendation. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SECOND REPORT OF THE STANDING COMMITTEE ON PROCEDURE-DAYS AND HOURS OF SITTING AND THE EFFECTIVE USE OF THE TIME OF THE HOUSE

The attached schedule sets out the Government's response to the recommendations made in the second report of the Procedure Committee. The response was discussed with the Procedure Committee prior to the double dissolution.

Before making some general observations about the report I should express the following qualifications to the Government's acceptance of changes. Any revised sessional orders which are adopted will be subject to review-the fact that they are being advanced as sessional orders indicates that they would be `on trial'. As well, I find myself in agreement with the Member for New England when he said during debate on the report that `it will really be quite necessary for us to review the whole of our procedures and practices in the new Parliament House'. We shall have to see how any revised orders which are adopted work, and we will have to consider further changes in the light of experience in the new Parliament House.

Turning to the report, the principal area of agreement between the Government and the Committee is a recognition of the need to foster opportunities for private Members. The Government believes that the best opportunities for Members come in the course of debate on legislation before the Parliament, but it acknowledges the value of the other forums provided especially for private Members. The Government has worked to ensure that these other opportunities are not lost in the pressure of Government business, and a look at the statistics over recent years will demonstrate a steady improvement.

The number of sitting days was increased in 1986 to 79, compared with 66 in 1985. The sitting pattern this year provides for 77 sitting days. The result has been that the Government has been required on fewer occasions to call on business at the expense of grievances, general business, the adjournment debate or discussion of matters of public importance, and has been able to accommodate lengthy debate on the more significant pieces of legislation coming before the House.

I note also in passing that the Government, like the Committee, is conscious of the need to safeguard the health of Members in what is a difficult and demanding work environment. We have worked successfully over the last couple of years to dramatically reduce the number of sittings extending beyond 11 o'clock, and despite the Committee's recommendation we will retain the early rising on Wednesday nights as the general rule.

To further facilitate opportunities for private Members, the Government proposes, in line with the Committee's recommendation, to turn Thursday mornings, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., over to private Members' business. I have suggested to the Procedure Committee that the order of business might be Prayers, presentation of petitions, presentation and consideration of committee reports, private Members' business (incorporating notices and orders of the day), grievance debate and a period for 90 second statements.
The Government does not oppose the suggested selection committee which would determine priorities for business on Thursday mornings.
The future of private members' time will depend to an extent on the attitude of members themselves. If successful, it might in time be extended and lead to further opportunities.
If, however, it were to prove disruptive or suffered from poor organisation or participation, its days may be shortlived.
So as not to significantly reduce the time available for Government business, the daily adjournment debate would be shortened from 45 minutes to 30.
Amongst the other recommendations which the Government accepts as adding to the efficiency of the House are:
revised procedures for tabling of ministerial papers;
discontinuation of the procedure of announcing messages from the Senate where no further action by the House is required;
ensuring that second reading speeches are kept as brief as possible and that non-critical matters of detail are included in explanatory memoranda; and

revised procedures for the presentation of petitions on Thursday mornings (although the Government sees no reason to vary the practice of the Clerk reading petitions in favour of the Chair making the announcement).
The Government does not oppose several other recommendations advanced by the Committee but believes that they are matters on which all members should be able to express their views freely. These are:

firstly, that the quorum of the House be reduced from one third of the whole number of the members to one fifth. The Government notes the very much smaller quorum size in comparable Parliaments, and the fact that previous attempts have been made to reduce the quorum, but has no firm view on the recommendation. The Government is, however, opposed to the development of a House duty roster in the way suggested;
secondly, that there be a return to the prohibition on reading speeches (subject to the exceptions outlined in the report); and

thirdly, that changes be made to the procedures relating to discussion of the matter of public importance. The Government notes that the Committee refers to this as de facto Opposition time (even though the Government can initiate matters) and will not force changes on the Opposition if it disagrees with the recommendations.
In several areas the Government does not accept the recommendations of the Committee.

On the question of days and hours of sitting, the Government does not accept that there should be a prescribed minimum number of sitting weeks. As I have mentioned, we are moving towards a 20 week sitting pattern as a natural adjustment to the amount of business before the House and the increased numbers, but the Government believes it important that it retain the flexibility to set the pattern according to circumstances. Nor does the Government believe it possible to adhere to a rigid two week on two off pattern. We aim for this, but in practice it is very difficult to achieve. For example, in developing the pattern an effort is made to minimise sittings during school holidays and public holi- days, State visits and the like, and this does not sit easily with a regular two on/two off pattern.

The Government gave considerable thought to the recommendation that the fortnightly pattern be altered to provide for two weeks of Monday/Thursday sittings before deciding against any change. Great significance is attached to having a clear day at the start of a 2 or 3 week sitting period to accommodate Cabinet or other meetings, and I suspect that the opposition parties attach similar value to the time. In coming to its decision the Government was also influenced by the fact that 34% of Members canvassed thought that there should be no change to the pattern.

The strong response in support of strict adherence to the 11.00 o'clock rising has also been noted. The Government will not be bound by an 11.00 o'clock rising, but is sympathetic to the concerns underlying the recommendation and will continue its effort to ensure that late sittings are kept to a minimum. I once again invite Members to review our efforts over the last couple of years.
The Government does not accept the recommendation for the establishment of a business committee.

The Honourable Member for Herbert in his dissenting report quite correctly points out that the programming of the House must remain the prerogative of the Government of the day-both to carry out its policies and to respond to contingencies.

Finally, the Government is not convinced of the need for legislation committees as recommended in the Report. It agrees with the comments made in the dissenting report of the Honourable Member for Herbert: the Committee has adduced insufficient evidence to support the establishment of such committees; there exists sufficient scope within the procedures of the House to ensure that legislation is given close scrutiny; and it is the duty of the House as a whole to undertake the deliberative legislative processes for the passage of a bill.
Committee recommendation
Government response
Total Hours of Sitting
That the House sit for a minimum of 20 weeks (80 days or 670 hours) each year.

Not accepted. The Government is responding to the pressure of business and the increased numbers by sitting longer. The House sat for 20 weeks last year and is scheduled to sit for 19 weeks this year. But the Government believes that it should retain the flexibility to adjust the number of sitting weeks according to demand.
Patterns of Sitting
That:
the current pattern of 2 sitting weeks followed by 2 non-sitting weeks continue;
The Government aims for this, but in practice it is very difficult to achieve while attempting to avoid clashing with school holidays, public holidays, Ministerial commitments etc.
sittings be from Monday to Thursday each sitting week;
Not accepted. The Government believes it important that there be a non sitting day at the commencement of each parliamentary sitting period.

sittings commence at 2 p.m. on Mondays and Tuesdays and 10 a.m. on Wednesdays and Thursdays, there be regular meal breaks and the House rise by 10.30 p.m. each sitting day and if the adjournment is negatived, the House rise at 11 p.m. after an adjournment debate of 30 minutes.

Not accepted. The Government is aware of the importance of the adjournment debate and the need to ensure that late sittings are avoided wherever possible. However, there will be occasions when it is necessary to negate the adjournment and sit beyond 11 p.m.
Business Programming

That a business committee be established, comprising the Speaker (or Chairman of Committees) as non-voting Chairman, the Leader of the House (or nominee), the Manager of Opposition Business (or nominee), the Government Whip (or Deputy Whip), the Opposition Whip (or Deputy), the Chairman of the proposed Selection Committee (or nominee from the Committee) and 2 back bench Members.
Not accepted. The Government agrees with the views contained in the dissenting report by Mr Lindsay that programming must remain the prerogative of the Government.
Private Members' Opportunities
That 2 hours each week be set aside for private Members' business and a unique method of selection be introduced by giving a role to a selection committee comprised largely of back bench Members.

Accepted. The Government would be prepared to support a block of four hours (from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.) rather than the two recommended by the Committee. So as not to significantly reduce the time available for Government business the daily adjournment debate would be cut to 30 minutes.
The Government does not oppose the selection committee as recommended nor the procedures proposed.
Members' Statements
That 15 minutes each day be set aside for Members' statements when Members could address the House briefly (up to 90 seconds) on matters of interest.
Not accepted. The Government would, however, have no difficulty with 90 second statements forming a part of private Members' business on Thursday mornings.
Adjournment Debate

Provided a period of 15 minutes for Members' statements is introduced, the adjournment debate be of 30 minutes duration and it be broadcast on days the House is broadcast, the moving of the closure be prohibited and provision for negativing the adjournment be retained with the provision that there will be an adjournment debate of 30 minutes duration and the House rise by 11 p.m.
A reduction in the time available for the adjournment debate would be a consequence of giving time to private members on Thursday mornings.

Given that 4 hours of private Members' business would be broadcast each Thursday morning, the Government does not consider the costs and staffing implications for the ABC in broadcasting the adjournment can be justified.
As mentioned above, the Government does not accept a compulsory adjournment debate.
Grievance Debate
That provided there is a guaranteed adjournment debate, a 15 minute period for Members' statements and a 2 hour block of private Members' business, the grievance debate procedure be abolished.
The Government believes that some time might be given to grievances during the time allotted to private Members on Thursday mornings.
Matters of Public Importance

The procedure be renamed Matters of Public Interest (to more realistically describe the nature of discussion), discussion be limited to one hour on three sitting days each week and speech time limits be restricted to 10 minutes.
The Government is not opposed to this recommendation but would be influenced by the Opposition's reaction.
Presentation and Consideration of Committee and Delegation Reports
That procedures be regularised, 45 minutes being set aside each week for the presentation of and debate on committee and delegation reports.
The proposed Business Committee would have a decisive role in determining the order of business and times for debate.

The Government accepts that time should be made available for committee and delegation reports. The Government considers that presentation and debate of committee reports should form part of the routine of business on Thursday mornings.
(See previous comments on Business Committee.)
Legislation Committees
That legislation committees be re-introduced to examine in detail such Bills as are referred by the House on the recommendation of the Business Committee.

Not accepted. The Government believes that it is the duty of the House by itself, or as a committee of the whole, to undertake the deliberative legislative processes for the passage of a Bill. (See previous comments on Business committee.
Removal of Procedures From the Chamber

Procedures for presentation of ministerial papers be streamlined (with Ministers retaining the option to present papers individually should they so wish) and the Business Committee having power to recommend to the House that papers be scheduled for debate or reference to a parliamentary committee.

Accepted. However, as previously noted, the Government does not accept the recommendations for a Business Committee and it would be for the Opposition parties to indicate those papers which they wanted noted.
That announcement of messages from the Senate on which no further action by the House was required be discontinued.
Accepted.
Reading Speeches
That subject to certain exceptions a prohibition on the reading of speeches be reintroduced.
The Government is not opposed to this recommendation but considers this to be a matter on which Members should be free to express an opinion.
Ministers' Second Reading Speeches
That guidelines for the preparation of second reading speeches be reviewed to ensure that matters of detail not critical to the speeches are included in explanatory memoranda.
Accepted.
Petitions

That the announcement of petitions be restricted to one day each week, lodgment being by 6pm the evening previous to that meeting; that the announcement include the number of signatories (counting to be the responsibility of the Member lodging the petition) and the aggregate number of signatures for identical petitions; that petitioners be required to state their addresses; that petitions obviously promoted by Members be ruled out of order; that Ministers be given the option to respond to petitions.
Accepted. The Government believes that the announcement of petitions should be the first time of business each Thursday morning.

The Government does not agree, however, that the Chair should make the announcement rather than the Clerk. Reading of petitions by the Clerk is long-established practice and does not in any way diminish its importance.
That storage and disposal arrangements be developed and implemented.

The question of making resources available for the assessment of the administrative and research value of petitions stored in Archives, and the development and implementation of appropriate storage and disposal arrangements is being taken up by the Speaker.
Quorum

That legislative action be taken to reduce the quorum to one-fifth of Members and each party represented in the House roster one-fifth of its Members for House duty to ensure a quorum is present at all times.
The Government is not opposed to a reduction in the Quorum size but as in the past this is a matter on which Members should be free to vote.
However, the Government opposes the development of a House duty roster, believing it to be unworkable.
